Ah. I did an indepth study on my website (which I won't post for fear of spam) that discussed the small cellular process of burning fat.

The cells have what's called "mitochondria" that convert stored or eaten energy (fat, carbs, and protein) into ATP, the body's main and quickest energy source - kind of like an "energy adapter".

The mitochondria actually lives in living cells in the body, and the more used the living cell is (like muscle, or organ tissue) the more mitochondria actually have in the body.

The more of these "powerhouse" organelles, as most call them, the better the body is at converting fat into energy. This is why most people say that the more muscle you have, the faster your metabolism is - because your muscle has some of the most mitochondria in the body.

The mitochondria convert fats, carbs, and sometimes protein into ATP, which is the broken to kind of perform a fueling type effect. When your cells need energy, this process continues. When your cells need a lot of energy (like with exercise, or vigorous activity) these mitochondria work overtime to produce even more energy, thus, burning more fat.
